item.title: Org-mode: The Swiss-Army Knife
item.description: This is going to be a multi-part series on Emacs and org-mode. This is also going to be a really long series, so before we begin I want to give you an idea of what to expect. What I'm about to present is a workflow I've tweaked over several years. It is a workflow that has constantly evolved to adapt to my varying needs. At the time of writing, I have completed 3478 todo items, and written over 29000 lines in my personal knowledge base.

item.title: Setting up OCaml and Emacs with Nix/NixOS
item.description: I'm learning OCaml via Real World OCaml, and getting a isolated OCaml development environment working with NixOS proved to be quite a struggle. This is a tutorial that describes my way of getting OCaml set up. Obtaining the OCaml Libraries OCaml and the more popular libraries are available in Nixpkgs, so one can write a simple shell.nix file to make them available in a nix shell: with import <nixpkgs> {}; let ocamlPackages = pkgs.

item.title: Litmus Tests for Writing Code
item.description: Here are some questions you can ask yourself when evaluating the code you write: API Modularity: Can you describe well your API, if written in a purely human language with no code extracts? Compactness: Does an experienced user need a manual? Orthogonality: Does changing a part of code affect other system properties? Single Point of Truth: Do data structures have states with 1-1 correspondence with the states of the real-world system?
